{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}}{{Use British English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox newspaper |name = Charlie Hebdo |image = Charlie Hebdo logo.svg |caption = |type = Satirical weekly news magazine |format = [[Berliner (format)|Berliner]] |foundation = 1970{{Harvnb|McNab|2006|p=26}}: "Georges Bernier, the real name of 'Professor Choron', [… was] cofounder and director of the satirical magazine ''Hara Kiri'', whose title was changed (to circumvent a ban, it seems!) to ''Charlie Hebdo'' in 1970." |ceased publication = 1981 |relaunched = 1992 |owners = [[Riss (cartoonist)|Riss]] (70%), Éric Portheault (30%)[http://www.telerama.fr/medias/denis-robert-l-histoire-de-charlie-hebdo-est-shakespearienne,136555.php Denis Robert : “L’histoire de ‘Charlie Hebdo’ est shakespearienne”], ''Télérama'', 8 janvier 2016. |political = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]]
[[Anti-clericalism]] |headquarters = Paris, France |editor = [[Gérard Biard]] |website = {{URL|http://www.charliehebdo.fr/}} |circulation = |ISSN = 1240-0068 }} '''''Charlie Hebdo''''' ({{IPA-fr|ʃaʁli ɛbdo}}; French for ''Charlie Weekly'') is a French [[satirical]] weekly magazine,{{cite news |title=Charlie Hebdo: first cover since terror attack depicts prophet Muhammad |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/jan/13/charlie-hebdo-cover-magazine-prophet-muhammad |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=13 January 2015 |accessdate=13 January 2015}} featuring cartoons,{{cite news|title=2 vendors arrested for selling newspaper with Hebdo cartoon|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/update-2-vendors-arrested-for-selling-newspaper-with-hebdo-cartoon/15965172|accessdate=5 February 2015|issue=Mid-Day.com|publisher=[[Mid Day]]}} reports, polemics, and jokes. Irreverent and stridently non-conformist in tone, the publication describes itself as above all [[secular]], [[skepticism|skeptic]],{{cite web|title=The Charlie Hebdo Conspiracy Too Crazy Even for Alex Jones|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/01/14/the-charlie-hebdo-conspiracy-too-crazy-even-for-alex-jones.html|publisher=www.thedailybeast.com|accessdate=20 January 2015}} and [[Atheism|atheist]],{{cite web|title=REFILE-No rules, no regrets for French cartoonists in Mohammad storm|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/19/film-protests-charlie-idUSL5E8KJE6320120919|publisher=Reuters.|accessdate=}} [[Far-left politics|far-left-wing]],{{cite web|title=Charlie Hebdo and its place in French journalism|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-15551998|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Charlie Hebdo: Gun attack on French magazine kills 12|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30710883|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 January 2015}} and [[anti-racist]]{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/idees/article/2013/11/20/non-charlie-hebdo-n-est-pas-raciste_3516646_3232.html |title=Non, "Charlie Hebdo" n’est pas raciste ! |work=[[Le Monde]] |accessdate=4 March 2014 |author=Charb}} publishing articles about the [[Extreme right in French politics|extreme right]] (especially the French nationalist [[National Front (France)|National Front]] party),{{cite web|title=Charlie Hebdo: They're Not Racist Just Because You're Offended|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/lliana-bird/charlie-hebdo_b_6461030.html|work=Huffingtonpost|accessdate=22 January 2015}} religion ([[Catholicism in France|Catholicism]], [[Islam in France|Islam]], [[Judaism in France|Judaism]]), [[Politics of France|politics]] and [[Culture of France|culture]]. The magazine has been the target of two terrorist attacks, in 2011 and 2015. Both were presumed to be in response to a number of controversial [[Muhammad]] cartoons it published. In [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|the second of these attacks]], 12 people were killed, including publishing director [[Charb]] and several other prominent cartoonists. ''Charlie Hebdo'' first appeared in 1970 as a companion to the monthly ''[[Hara-Kiri (magazine)|Hara-Kiri]]'' magazine, after a previous title was banned for mocking the death of former French President [[Charles de Gaulle]].{{cite news |url=http://time.com/3657256/charlie-hebdo-paris-attack/ |title=The Provocative History of French Weekly Newspaper Charlie Hebdo |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=11 January 2015 |author=Megan Gibson}} In 1981 publication ceased, but the magazine was resurrected in 1992. Its current [[editor-in-chief]] is [[Gérard Biard]]. The previous editors were [[François Cavanna]] (1970–1981) and [[Philippe Val]] (1992–2009). The magazine is published every Wednesday, with special editions issued on an unscheduled basis. == Origins in ''Hara-Kiri'' == [[File:François Cavanna.jpg|thumb|300px|[[François Cavanna]] (1923–2014), one of the founders of the first ''Charlie Hebdo'' title]] In 1960, [[Professeur Choron|Georges "Professeur Choron" Bernier]] and [[François Cavanna]] launched a monthly magazine entitled ''[[Hara-Kiri (magazine)|Hara-Kiri]]''.{{Harvnb|Lemonnier|2008|p=50}}. Choron acted as the director of publication and Cavanna as its editor. Eventually Cavanna gathered together a team which included [[Roland Topor]], [[Fred Aristidès|Fred]], [[Jean-Marc Reiser]], [[Georges Wolinski]], {{Interlanguage link multi|Gébé|fr}}, and [[Cabu]]. After an early reader's letter accused them of being "dumb and nasty" ("bête et méchant"), the phrase became an official slogan for the magazine and made it into everyday language in France. ''Hara-Kiri'' was briefly banned in 1961, and again for six months in 1966. A few contributors did not return along with the newspaper, such as Gébé, Cabu, Topor, and Fred. New members of the team included {{Interlanguage link multi|Delfeil de Ton|fr}}, {{Interlanguage link multi|Pierre Fournier (journaliste)|fr}}, and [[Bernard Willem Holtrop|Willem]]. In 1969, the ''Hara-Kiri'' team decided to produce a weekly publication – on top of the existing monthly magazine – which would focus more on current affairs. This was launched in February as ''[[Hara-Kiri (magazine)|Hara-Kiri Hebdo]]'' and renamed ''L'Hebdo Hara-Kiri'' in May of the same year.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/press/what-is-charlie-hebdo-banned-and-resurrected-but-always-in-the-grand-tradition-of-gallic-satire-9963721.html |title=What is Charlie Hebdo? A magazine banned and resurrected but always in the grand tradition of Gallic satire |last1=Sherwin |first1=Adam |date=16 January 2015 |website=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=16 January 2015}} (''Hebdo'' is short for ''hebdomadaire'' – "weekly") == Launch of Charlie Hebdo == In November 1970, the former French president [[Charles de Gaulle]] died in his home village of [[Colombey-les-Deux-Églises]], eight days after a disaster in a nightclub, the [[Club Cinq-Sept fire]], which caused the death of 146 people. The magazine released a cover spoofing the popular press's coverage of this disaster, headlined "Tragic Ball at Colombey, one dead." As a result, the weekly was banned. In order to sidestep the ban, the editorial team decided to change its title, and used ''Charlie Hebdo''. The new name was derived from a monthly comics magazine called ''Charlie'' (later renamed ''[[Charlie Mensuel]]'', meaning ''Charlie Monthly''), which had been started by Bernier and Delfeil de Ton in 1969. The monthly ''Charlie'' took its name from the lead character of one of the comics it originally published, ''[[Peanuts]]''{{'}}s [[Charlie Brown]]. Using that title for the new weekly magazine was also an inside joke about Charles de Gaulle.[http://www.lemonde.fr/livres/article/2006/02/14/cavanna-et-les-cons_741216_3260.html Cavanna et "les cons"], ''Le Monde'', 14 February 2014[http://www.lyoncapitale.fr/Journal/France-monde/Culture/Vie-et-politique-culturelle/Quelle-est-l-origine-du-nom-Charlie-Hebdo Quelle est l’origine du nom Charlie Hebdo ?], ''Lyon Capitale'', 12 janvier 2015[http://www.directmatin.fr/bd/2015-01-08/pourquoi-charlie-hebdo-sappelle-charlie-hebdo-697511 Pourquoi Charlie Hebdo s'appelle Charlie Hebdo], ''Direct Matin'', 8 January 2015 The first issue did feature a ''Peanuts'' strip, as the editors were fans of the series.[http://www.liberation.fr/evenement/2000/02/14/wolinski-ex-redacteur-en-chef-de-charlie-mensuel-se-souvient-de-peanuts-ca-serait-bien-de-renouer-av_315824 Wolinski L'ex-rédacteur en chef de «Charlie mensuel», se souvient de «Peanuts» «Ça serait bien de renouer avec ce genre de BD»], ''Libération'', 4 février 2000 In December 1981, publication ceased.{{cite web|last1=Abbruzzese|first1=Jason|title=What is Charlie Hebdo? Behind the covers of the French satirical magazine targeted in deadly attack|url=http://mashable.com/2015/01/07/charlie-hebdo-magazine/|website=Mashable.com|accessdate=16 February 2015}} == Rebirth == In 1991, Gébé, Cabu and others were reunited to work for ''[[La Grosse Bertha]]'', a new weekly magazine resembling ''Charlie Hebdo'' created in reaction to the [[Gulf War|First Gulf War]] and edited by singer and comedian [[Philippe Val]]. However, the following year, Val clashed with the publisher, who wanted apolitical humour, and was fired. Gébé and Cabu walked out with him and decided to launch their own paper again. The three called upon Cavanna, Delfeil de Ton and Wolinski, requesting their help and input. After much searching for a new name, the obvious idea of resurrecting ''Charlie Hebdo'' was agreed on. The new magazine was owned by Val, Gébé, Cabu and singer [[Renaud]]. Val was editor, Gébé publication director. The publication of the new ''Charlie Hebdo'' began in July 1992 amidst much publicity. The first issue under the new publication sold 100,000 copies. Choron, who had fallen out with his former colleagues, tried to restart a weekly ''Hara-Kiri'', but its publication was short-lived. Choron died in January 2005. On 26 April 1996, [[François Cavanna]], [[Charb]] and Philippe Val filed 173,704 signatures, obtained in eight months, with the aim of [[ban (law)|banning]] the political party [[National Front (France)|Front National]], since it would have contravened the articles 1, 2, 4, 6 and 7 of the [[Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen]].Antoine Guiral, "[http://ecrans.liberation.fr/ecrans/1996/09/12/les-173-704-signatures-de-charlie-hebdo_183854 Les 173 704 signatures de Charlie Hebdo]" in ''[[Libération]]'', 12 September 1996. In 2000, journalist Mona Chollet was sacked after she had protested against a Philippe Val article which called [[Palestinian people|Palestinians]] "non-civilised".[http://lmsi.net/L-opinion-du-Patron L’opinion du patron], ''Les Mots Sont Importants'', 4 March 2006. In 2004, following the death of Gébé, Val succeeded him as director of publication, while still holding his position as editor.{{cite web|last1=Chabert|first1=Chrystel|title=Philippe Val : "Il ne faut pas que mes amis soient morts pour rien"|url=http://culturebox.francetvinfo.fr/livres/evenements/philippe-val-il-ne-faut-pas-que-mes-amis-soient-morts-pour-rien-209001|website=francetvinfo.fr|publisher=France TV Info|accessdate=16 February 2015}} In 2008, controversy broke over a column by veteran cartoonist [[Siné]] which led to accusations of antisemitism and Siné's sacking by Val. Siné successfully sued the newspaper for unfair dismissal and ''Charlie Hebdo'' was ordered to pay him €90,000 in damages.[http://www.liberation.fr/medias/2012/12/17/charlie-hebdo-doit-verser-90-000-euros-a-sine_868176 ''Charlie Hebdo'' doit verser 90 000 euros à Siné], ''Libération'', 17 December 2012. Siné launched a rival paper called ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Siné Hebdo|fr}}'' which later became ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Siné Mensuel|fr}}''. In 2009, Philippe Val resigned after being appointed director of [[France Inter]], a public radio station to which he has contributed since the early 1990s. His functions were split between two cartoonists, Charb and [[Riss (cartoonist)|Riss]]. Val gave away his shares in 2011. As of March 2011, ''Charlie Hebdo'' was owned by Charb (600 shares), Riss (599 shares), finance director Éric Portheault (299 shares), and Cabu and Bernard Maris with one share each.{{cite web|title=Cabu reste actionnaire de Charlie Hebdo|url=http://charlieenchaine.free.fr/?+Cabu-reste-actionnaire-de-Charlie+|website=Charlie Enchaîné|accessdate=18 January 2015}} [[Gérard Biard]] is the [[editor-in-chief]] of ''Charlie Hebdo''.{{cite news|author1=Adam Withnall|author2=John Lichfield|title=Charlie Hebdo shooting: At least 12 killed as shots fired at satirical magazine's Paris office|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-shooting-10-killed-as-shots-fired-at-satirical-magazine-headquarters-according-to-reports-9962337.html|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=The Independent|date=7 January 2015|location=Paris}} On 5 May 2015 Charlie Hebdo was awarded the PEN/Toni and James C. Goodale Freedom of Expression Courage Award at the [[PEN American Center]] Literary Gala in New York City.{{cite news|last=Susman|first=Tina|title=At PEN Gala, Charlie Hebdo editor calls for free expression and debate|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-pen-awards-20150505-story.html|accessdate=22 November 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=5 May 2015}} == Legal issues == === ''Mosque of Paris v Val'' (2007) === In 2007 the [[Grand Mosque of Paris]] began criminal proceedings against the chief-editor of ''Charlie Hebdo'', Philipe Val, under [[Hate speech laws in France|France's hate speech laws]] for publicly abusing a group on the ground of their religion. The lawsuit was limited to three specific cartoons, including one depicting Muhammad carrying a bomb in his turban. In March 2007 a Paris court acquitted Val, finding that it was fundamentalists, rather than Muslims, who were being ridiculed in the cartoons.Janssen, Esther, "Limits to Expression on Religion in France" (8 March 2012). ''Agama & Religiusitas di Eropa, Journal of European Studies'', Vol. V, No. 1, pp. 22–45, 2009. Produced in cooperation between the University of Indonesia and the Delegation of the European Commission.; Amsterdam Law School Research Paper No. 2012–45; Institute for Information Law Research Paper No. 2012–39. Available at SSRN: [http://ssrn.com/abstract=2018277 SSRN] === Siné sacking (2008) === On 2 July 2008, a column by the cartoonist [[Siné]] (Maurice Sinet) appeared in ''Charlie Hebdo'' citing a rumour that [[Jean Sarkozy]], son of [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], had announced his intention to convert to [[Judaism]] before marrying his fiancée, Jewish heiress Jessica Sebaoun-[[Darty]]. Siné added, "he'll go far, this lad!"{{cite web|last1=Leprince|first1=Chloé|title=L'Affaire Siné|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/sep/17/religion.france|website=The Guardian|accessdate=9 May 2015}} This led to complaints of antisemitism. The magazine's editor, [[Philippe Val]], ordered Siné to write a letter of apology or face termination. The cartoonist said he would rather "cut his own balls off," and was promptly fired. Both sides subsequently filed lawsuits, and in December 2010, Siné won a 40,000 euros court judgment against his former publisher for [[wrongful termination]].[http://www.actuabd.com/+Le-Tribunal-de-Grande-Instance+ "Le Tribunal de Grande Instance donne raison à Siné contre Charlie Hebdo,"] ActuaBD (11 December 2010). == Muhammad cartoons and aftermath == [[File:Paris 2006-02-11 anti-caricature protest bannieres dsc07473.jpg|thumb|right|Muslims march in Paris on 11 February 2006 against the publication of caricatures of Muhammad. A sign with "Charlie Hebdo" circled and crossed-out is held aloft in the picture's upper middle.]] [[File:Charliehebdo.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Image of 3 November 2011 cover of ''Charlie Hebdo'', renamed ''[[Charia Hebdo]]'' ("[[Sharia]] Hebdo"). The [[word balloon]] reads "100 lashes if you don't die laughing!"]] === 2006 publication === Controversy arose over the publication's edition of 9 February 2006. Under the title "''Mahomet débordé par les intégristes''" ("Muhammad overwhelmed by fundamentalists"), the front page showed a cartoon of a weeping [[Muhammad]] saying "''C'est dur d'être aimé par des cons''" ("it's hard being loved by jerks"). The newspaper reprinted the twelve cartoons of the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|''Jyllands-Posten'' Muhammad cartoons controversy]] and added some of their own. Compared to a regular circulation of 100,000 sold copies, this edition enjoyed great commercial success. 160,000 copies were sold and another 150,000 were in print later that day. In response, French President [[Jacques Chirac]] condemned "overt provocations" which could inflame passions. "Anything that can hurt the convictions of someone else, in particular religious convictions, should be avoided", Chirac said. The [[Grand Mosque of Paris]], the [[Muslim World League]] and the [[Union of Islamic Organisations of France|Union of French Islamic Organisations]] (UOIF) sued, claiming the cartoon edition included racist cartoons.{{cite web|url=http://www.cfcm.tv/2007/03/22/caricatures-charlie-hebdo-relaxe/|title=Culte Musulman et Islam de France|publisher=CFCM TV|date=22 March 2007 |accessdate=21 December 2011}} A later edition contained a statement by a group of twelve writers warning against [[Islamism]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4764730.stm |title=Writers' statement on cartoons (1 March 2006)|publisher=BBC News|date=1 March 2006|accessdate=21 December 2011}} The suit by the Grand Mosque and the UOIF reached the courts in February 2007. Publisher [[Philippe Val]] contended "It is racist to imagine that they can't understand a joke," but Francis Szpiner, the lawyer for the Grand Mosque, explained the suit: "Two of those caricatures make a link between Muslims and Muslim terrorists. That has a name and it's called racism."{{cite web|last=Heneghan|first=Tom|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/world/cartoon-row-goes-to-french-court-1.313615|title=Cartoon row goes to French court|work=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]]|date=2 February 2007}} Future president [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] sent a letter to be read in court expressing his support for the ancient French tradition of satire.{{cite web|url=http://lci.tf1.fr/france/societe/2007-02/soutien-sarkozy-charlie-hebdo-fache-cfcm-4889140.html|title=Caricatures : Le soutien de Sarkozy à Charlie Hebdo fâche le CFCM|work=TF1 News|date=15 December 2011|accessdate=21 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111205220532/http://lci.tf1.fr/france/societe/2007-02/soutien-sarkozy-charlie-hebdo-fache-cfcm-4889140.html|archivedate=5 December 2011|df=dmy-all}} [[François Bayrou]] and future president [[François Hollande]] also expressed their support for [[Freedom of speech|freedom of expression]]. The [[French Council of the Muslim Faith]] (CFCM) criticised the expression of these sentiments, claiming that they were politicising a court case.{{cite web|url=http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/societe/sarkozy-accuse-de-politiser-le-proces_462776.html|title=Charlie Hebdo: Sarkozy accusé de politiser le procès|work=L'Express|accessdate=21 December 2011}} On 22 March 2007, executive editor Val was acquitted by the court.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6479673.stm|title=French cartoons editor acquitted|work=[[BBC]]|date=22 March 2007}} The court followed the state attorney's reasoning that two of the three cartoons were not an attack on Islam, but on Muslim terrorists, and that the third cartoon with Muhammad with a bomb in his turban should be seen in the context of the magazine in question, which attacked religious fundamentalism.{{cite web|url=http://www.newswiretoday.com/news/13842/|title=French Satirical Newspaper 'Charlie Hebdo' Wins Second Trial Over Controversial Cartoon Ban Request|work=Newswire}} [[File:20111102 Incendie Charlie Hebdo Paris XXe 07.jpg|thumb|left|Debris outside the paper's offices following the November 2011 attack]] === November 2011 firebombing === In November 2011, the newspaper's office in the [[20th arrondissement of Paris|20th arrondissement]]Schofield, Hugh. "[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15551998 Charlie Hebdo and its place in French journalism]." [[BBC]]. 3 November 2011.{{cite news|author=James Boxel|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/75f87b24-0541-11e1-a3d1-00144feabdc0.html |title=Firebomb attack on satirical French magazine |newspaper=Financial Times|date=2 November 2011|accessdate=19 September 2012}} was fire-bombed and its website hacked. The attacks were presumed to be linked to its decision to rename the edition of 3 November 2011 "[[Charia Hebdo]]", with Muhammad listed as the "editor-in-chief".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15550350|title=Attack on French satirical paper Charlie Hebdo (2 November 2011)|publisher=BBC|date=2 November 2011|accessdate=21 December 2011}} The cover, featuring a cartoon of Muhammad saying: "100 lashes of the whip if you don't die laughing" by [[Luz (cartoonist)|Luz]] (Rénald Luzier), had circulated on social media for a couple of days. The "Charia Hebdo" issue had been a response to recent news of the post-election introduction of sharia law in Libya and the victory of the Islamist party in Tunisia.{{cite news|title=Satirical French magazine names 'Muhammad' as editor|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-15536684|accessdate=19 January 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=1 November 2011}} It especially focuses on oppression of women under sharia, taking aim at domestic violence, mandatory veiling, burquas, restrictions on freedom, forced marriage, and stoning of those accused of adultery. It also targeted oppression of gays and dissenters, and practices such as stoning, flogging, hand/foot/tongue amputations, polygamy, forced marriage, and early indoctrination of children. "Guest editor" Muhammad is portrayed as a good-humoured voice of reason, decrying the recent elections and calling for a separation between politics and religion, while stating that Islam is compatible with humour.{{cite web|url=https://bogardiner.wordpress.com/2015/01/18/a-closer-look-at-sharia-hebdo-for-which-charlie-hebdo-offices-were-firebombed-in-2011/|title=A closer look at "Sharia Hebdo," for which Charlie Hebdo was firebombed in 2011|last=Gardiner|first=Bo|date=18 January 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=|accessdate=}} The magazine responded to the bombing by distributing some four times the usual number of copies.{{cite news|title=French paper reprints Mohammad cartoon after fire-bomb|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-france-fire-magazine-idUSTRE7A26MO20111103|accessdate=19 January 2015|agency=Reuters|date=3 November 2011}} Charb was quoted by [[Associated Press]] stating that the attack might have been carried out by "stupid people who don't know what Islam is" and that they are "idiots who betray their own religion". [[Mohammed Moussaoui]], head of the [[French Council of the Muslim Faith]], said his organisation deplores "the very mocking tone of the paper toward Islam and its prophet but reaffirms with force its total opposition to all acts and all forms of violence."{{cite news|last1=Ganley|first1=Elaine|title=Fire at French newspaper after Muhammad issue|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2011/11/02/fire_at_french_newspaper_after_muhammad_issue/?page=full|accessdate=16 February 2015|work=Boston.com|agency=Associated Press|date=2 November 2011}} [[François Fillon]], the prime minister, and [[Claude Guéant]], the interior minister, voiced support for ''Charlie Hebdo'', as did feminist writer [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], who criticised calls for self-censorship.{{cite news|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/11/09/extremists-hurt-non-militant-muslims-the-most|title=Extremists hurt non-militant Muslims the most|author=Peter Worthington|agency=QMI|newspaper=Toronto Sun|date=9 November 2011}} === 2012 cartoons depicting Muhammad === In September 2012, the newspaper published a series of satirical cartoons of Muhammad, some of which featured nude caricatures of him.[http://www.bfmtv.com/societe/charlie-hebdo-publie-pages-interieures-caricatures-mahomet-338598.html "Charlie Hebdo publie des caricatures de Mahomet"]. BMFTV {{fr icon}} Retrieved 19 September 2012.{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/09/19/magazines-nude-mohammad-cartoons-prompt-france-to-shut-embassies-schools-in-20-countries/ |title=Magazine's nude Mohammad cartoons prompt France to shut embassies, schools in 20 countries |agency=Reuters |work=National Post |date=19 September 2012 |accessdate=19 September 2012 |author=Vinocur, Nicholas}} Given that this issue came days after a [[2012 diplomatic missions attacks|series of attacks on US embassies]] in the Middle East, purportedly in response to the anti-Islamic film ''[[Innocence of Muslims]]'', the [[French government]] decided to increase security at certain French embassies, as well as to close the French embassies, consulates, cultural centres, and international schools in about 20 [[Muslim countries]].{{cite news|last=Samuel|first=Henry|title=France to close schools and embassies fearing Mohammed cartoon reaction|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/9553722/France-to-close-schools-and-embassies-fearing-Mohammed-cartoon-reaction.html|accessdate=20 September 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=19 September 2012}} In addition, [[Compagnies Républicaines de Sécurité|riot police]] surrounded the offices of the magazine to protect it against possible attacks.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/charlie-hebdo-cartoons-spark-debate-over-free-speech-and-islamophobia/2012/09/19/4b3ba988-026b-11e2-9b24-ff730c7f6312_blog.html |title=Charlie Hebdo cartoons spark debate over free speech and Islamophobia |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=19 September 2012 |accessdate=19 September 2012 |author=Khazan, Olga}}{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/19/charlie-hebdo-mohammed-cartoons_n_1896244.html |title=Charlie Charlie Hebdo Mohammed Cartoons: France Ups Embassy Security After Prophet Cartoons |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=19 September 2012 |accessdate=19 September 2012 |author1=Keller, Greg |author2=Hinnant, Lori }} Foreign Minister [[Laurent Fabius]] criticised the magazine's decision, saying, "In France, there is a principle of freedom of expression, which should not be undermined. In the present context, given this absurd video that has been aired, strong emotions have been awakened in many Muslim countries. Is it really sensible or intelligent to pour oil on the fire?"{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Nicola |title=French Magazine Publishes Cartoons Mocking Muhammad |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date=19 September 2012 |accessdate=19 September 2012 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/20/world/europe/french-magazine-publishes-cartoons-mocking-muhammad.html}} The US White House said "a French magazine published cartoons featuring a figure resembling the Prophet Muhammad, and obviously, we have questions about the judgment of publishing something like this."{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/09/19/press-briefing-press-secretary-jay-carney-91912|title=Press Briefing by Press Secretary Jay Carney, 19 September 2012|publisher=The White House}} However, the newspaper's editor defended publication of the cartoons, saying, "We do caricatures of everyone, and above all every week, and when we do it with the Prophet, it's called provocation."{{cite news |title=French leaders sound alarm over planned Mohammad cartoons |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=18 September 2012 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/18/us-protests-france-cartoons-idUSBRE88H1CX20120918 |accessdate=18 September 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/charlie-hebdo-editor-in-chief-on-muhammad-cartoons-a-856891.html|title='Charlie Hebdo' Editor in Chief: 'A Drawing Has Never Killed Anyone'|work=Der Spiegel|author=Stefan Simons|date=20 September 2012}} === 2015 attack === [[File:Charlie-Hebdo-2015-11.JPG|thumb|right|Journalists, policemen, and emergency services in the street of the shooting, a few hours after the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|January 2015 attack]]]] [[File:Je suis Charlie.svg|thumb|right|The ''[[Je suis Charlie]]'' ("I am Charlie") slogan became an endorsement of freedom of speech and press.]] [[File:Candles Against Terror.jpg|thumb|Indian journalists expressed solidarity with the victims of attack at New Delhi on 9 January 2015. Displayed cartoon by [[Shekhar Gurera]]]] {{Main|Charlie Hebdo shooting}} On 7 January 2015, two [[Islamist]] gunmen forced their way into the Paris headquarters of ''Charlie Hebdo'' and opened fire, killing twelve: staff cartoonists [[Charb]], [[Cabu]], [[Philippe Honoré (cartoonist)|Honoré]], [[Tignous]] and [[Georges Wolinski|Wolinski]],{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2015/01/07/les-dessinateurs-et-journalistes-tues_4550767_3224.html|title=Attentat contre " Charlie Hebdo " : Charb, Cabu, Wolinski et les autres, assassinés dans leur rédaction|work=Le Monde|language=French}} economist [[Bernard Maris]], editors [[Elsa Cayat]] and [[Mustapha Ourrad]], guest Michel Renaud, maintenance worker Frédéric Boisseau and police officers Brinsolaro and Merabet, and wounding eleven, four of them seriously.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-30708237 "Charlie Hebdo attack: What we know so far"], BBC News, 8 January 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/societe/en-direct-fusillade-a-charlie-hebdo-selon-i-tele-et-20-minutes-07-01-2015-1894629_23.php|title=EN DIRECT. Massacre chez "Charlie Hebdo" : 12 morts, dont Charb et Cabu|work=Le Point.fr| language=French}}{{cite news |url=http://www.lessentiel.lu/fr/news/france/story/22976860 |title=Les dessinateurs Charb et Cabu seraient morts |language=French|work=L'Essentiel|location=France |date=7 January 2015|accessdate=7 January 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3657246/paris-charlie-hebdo-shooting/|title=Paris Police Say 12 Dead After Shooting at Charlie Hebdo|quote=Witnesses said that the gunmen had called out the names of individual from the magazine. French media report that Charb, the ''Charlie Hebdo'' cartoonist who was on al-Qaeda's most wanted list in 2013, was seriously injured.|author=Conal Urquhart|work=Time}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11330505/Murdered-Charlie-Hebdo-cartoonist-was-on-al-Qaeda-wanted-list.html|title=Murdered Charlie Hebdo cartoonist was on al Qaeda wanted list|author=Victoria Ward|work=The Telegraph}} During the attack, the gunmen shouted "''[[Allahu akbar]]''" ("God is great" in [[Arabic]]) and also "the Prophet is avenged".{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/deadly-shooting-at-french-satirical-newspaper-report/article22329480/|title=The Globe in Paris: Police identify three suspects|work=The Globe and Mail}} President [[François Hollande]] described it as a "terrorist attack of the most extreme barbarity".Adam Withnall, John Lichfield, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-shooting-10-killed-as-shots-fired-at-satirical-magazine-headquarters-according-to-reports-9962337.html "Charlie Hebdo shooting: At least 12 killed as shots fired at satirical magazine's Paris office"], ''The Independent'', 7 January 2015. The two gunmen were identified as [[Saïd Kouachi]] and [[Chérif Kouachi]], French Muslim brothers of Algerian descent.{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Andrew|last2=de la Baume |first2= Maïa|title=Two Brothers Suspected in Killings Were Known to French Intelligence Services|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/08/world/two-brothers-suspected-in-killings-were-known-to-french-intelligence-services.html|accessdate=8 January 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 January 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/paris-shooting-two-police-officers-injured-in-assault-rifle-attack-hours-after-charlie-hebdo-killings-9964143.html|title=Paris shooting: Female police officer dead following assault rifle attack morning after Charlie Hebdo killings|work=The Independent|accessdate=9 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.liberation.fr/societe/2015/01/07/un-commando-organise-et-prepare_1175841|title=Un commando organisé|work=Libération|accessdate=8 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/paris-magazine-attack/three-suspects-named-paris-terror-attack-n281761|title=Paris Attack Suspect Dead, Two in Custody, U.S. Officials Say|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=8 January 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://journalistsresource.org/studies/international/conflicts/france-muslims-terrorism-and-challenges-of-integration-research-roundup|title=France, Islam, terrorism and the challenges of integration: Research roundup}} JournalistsResource.org, retrieved 23 January 2015. ==== {{anchor|Survivors' issue}}The "survivors' issue" ==== {{Main|Charlie Hebdo issue No. 1178}} The day after the attack, the remaining staff of ''Charlie Hebdo'' announced that publication would continue, with the following week's edition of the newspaper to be published according to the usual schedule with a [[print run]] of one million copies, up significantly from its usual 60,000.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/europe/Charlie-Hebdo-will-come-out-next-week-despite-bloodbath/articleshow/45809563.cms|title=Charlie Hebdo will come out next week, despite bloodbath|date=8 January 2015|work=The Times of India}}{{cite web|title=Charlie Hebdo Attack: Magazine to publish next week|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-30724863|publisher=BBC News|date=8 January 2015|accessdate=9 January 2015}} On 13 January 2015, the news came on BBC that the [[Charlie Hebdo "Survivors' issue"|first issue after the massacre]] will come out in three million copies.{{cite web |title=Defiant Charlie Hebdo depicts Prophet Muhammad on cover|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30790409|publisher=BBC News|date=13 January 2015|accessdate=13 January 2015}} On Wednesday itself it was announced that with a huge demand in France, the print run would be raised from three to five million copies.{{cite web |title=Charlie Hebdo Attack: Magazine to publish next week |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-30724863|publisher=BBC News |date=8 January 2015 |accessdate=9 January 2015}} The newspaper announced the revenue from the issue would go towards the families of the victims.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30808284|title=Charlie Hebdo attack: Print run for new issue expanded|date=14 January 2015|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=14 January 2014}} The French government granted nearly [[Euro|€]]1 million to support the magazine.{{cite news|title=Charlie Hebdo: Pellerin veut débloquer un million d'euros|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-eco/2015/01/08/97002-20150108FILWWW00371-charlie-hebdo-pellerin-veut-debloquer-un-million-d-euros.php|accessdate=9 January 2015|work=Le Figaro|date=8 January 2015|language=fr}} The [[Digital Innovation Press Fund]] (French: ''Fonds Google–AIPG pour l’Innovation Numérique de la presse''), partially funded by [[Google]], donated €250,000,{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/1/8/7514251/charlie-hebdo-will-publish-one-million-copies-next-week-with-help|title=Charlie Hebdo will publish one million copies next week|author= Russell Brandom|date=8 January 2015|work=The Verge}} matching a donation by the French Press and Pluralism Fund.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/french-media-raises-500000-to-keep-satirical-magazine-charlie-hebdo-open-9965576.html|title= French media raises €500,000 to keep satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo open|work=The Independent|date=8 January 2015|author=Jon Stone}} The [[Guardian Media Group]] pledged a donation of £100,000.{{cite news|url=http://news.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/01/08/updates-on-charlie-hebdo-shooting/|title=Updates on the 2nd Day of Search for Suspects in Charlie Hebdo Shooting|first1=Mike |last1=Mcphate|first2=Robert|last2=Mackey|date=8 January 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]}} ==== ''Je suis Charlie'' ==== {{Main|Je suis Charlie|l1=''Je suis Charlie''}} [[File:Charlie Hebdo Tout est pardonné.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The front cover of [[Charlie Hebdo issue No. 1178|edition of 14 January 2015]], with a cartoon in the same style as 3 November 2011 cover, uses the phrase "Je Suis Charlie". (Headline translation: "All is forgiven.") {{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11343077/How-I-created-the-Charlie-Hebdo-magazine-cover-cartoonist-Luzs-statement-in-full.html|title=How I created the Charlie Hebdo magazine cover: cartoonist Luz's statement in full|work=The Telegraph|date=13 January 2015}}]] After the attacks, the phrase ''{{lang|fr|Je suis Charlie}}'', French for "I am Charlie", was adopted by supporters of [[free speech]] and freedom of expression who were reacting to the shootings. The phrase identifies a speaker or supporter of those who were killed at the ''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting, and by extension, a supporter of freedom of speech and resistance to armed threats. Some journalists embraced the expression as a rallying cry for the freedom of self-expression.{{cite web|url=http://enisyavuz.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/jesuis05.png |title=image |publisher=Enis Yavuz |accessdate=8 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109002354/http://enisyavuz.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/jesuis05.png |archivedate=9 January 2015 |df=dmy }} The slogan was first used on [[Twitter]] and spread to the Internet at large. The Twitter account and the original "Je suis Charlie" picture bearing the phrase in white Charlie Hebdo style font on black background were created by French journalist and artist [[Joachim Roncin]] just after the massacre.{{cite web|title=#JeSuisCharlie creator: Phrase cannot be a trademark |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-30797059|publisher=BBC News|date=14 January 2015|accessdate=14 January 2015}} The website of ''Charlie Hebdo'' went offline shortly after the shooting, and when it returned it bore the legend ''Je Suis Charlie'' on a black background.{{cite web|url=http://www.charliehebdo.fr|title=Charlie Hedbo|date=7 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107120424/http://www.charliehebdo.fr/|archivedate=7 January 2015|df=dmy-all}} The statement was used as the [[hashtag]] #jesuischarlie on Twitter,{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/je-suis-charlie-trends-people-4935086|work=Daily Mirror|title='Je suis Charlie' trends as people refuse to be silenced by Charlie Hebdo gunmen|author=Richard Booth|date=7 January 2015}} as computer-printed or hand-made placards and stickers, and displayed on mobile phones at vigils, and on many websites, particularly media sites. While other symbols were used, notably holding pens in the air, the phrase "Not Afraid", and tweeting certain images, "''Je Suis Charlie''" became more widespread.{{cite news |url=http://ecrans.liberation.fr/ecrans/2015/01/09/charlie-s-installe-a-libe-bon-on-fait-le-journal_1177043|title=Charlie" s'installe à "Libé" : "Bon, on fait le journal ? |author=Isabelle Hanne |journal=Libération|accessdate=9 January 2015|language=French}} ==== Republican marches ==== {{Main|Republican marches}} A series of rallies took place in cities across France on 10–11 January 2015 to honour the victims of the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]], and also to voice support for [[freedom of speech]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2015-01-09/shots-fired-hostages-taken-in-town-northeast-of-paris.html |title=Paris Terror Suspects Killed in Twin French Police Raids |publisher=Bloomberg |date=9 January 2014 |accessdate=11 January 2015}} [[Luz (cartoonist)|Luz]], one of the survivors of the attack, stated: "People sang ''[[La Marseillaise]]''. We're speaking about the memory of Charb, Tignous, Cabu, Honoré, Wolinski: they would all have abhorred that kind of attitude."{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/culture/luz-le-soutien-a-charlie-hebdo-est-a-contre-sens-de-ses-dessins-10-01-2015-1895437_3.php|title=Luz: le soutien à Charlie Hebdo est à "contre-sens" de ses dessins|author=Le Point, magazine|work=Le Point.fr}} [[Bernard Willem Holtrop|Willem]], another surviving cartoonist, declared that "We vomit on those who suddenly declared that they were our friends".{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/societe/willem-vomit-sur-ceux-qui-subitement-disent-etre-nos-amis-10-01-2015-1895408_23.php|title=Willem : "Nous vomissons sur ceux qui, subitement, disent être nos amis"|author=Le Point, magazine|work=Le Point.fr}} ==== Other reactions ==== Unrest in [[Niger]] following the publication of the post-attack issue of ''Charlie Hebdo'' resulted in ten deaths,{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/17/us-france-shooting-niger-idUSKBN0KQ0BP20150117|title=Five killed in second day of Charlie Hebdo protests in Niger|agency=Reuters|accessdate=18 January 2015}} dozens injured, and at least nine churches burned.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/17/niger-protesters-burn-churches-charlie-hebdo-protest|title=Niger rioters torch churches and attack French firms in Charlie Hebdo protest|author=Emma Graham-Harrison|work=The Guardian|accessdate=18 January 2015}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported seven churches burned in [[Niamey]] alone. Churches were also reported to be on fire in eastern [[Maradi, Niger|Maradi]] and [[Goure]]. Violent demonstrations also were prevalent in [[Zinder]], where some burned French flags. There were violent demonstrations in Karachi in [[Pakistan]], where Asif Hassan, a photographer working for the [[Agence France-Presse]], was seriously injured by a shot to the chest. In Algiers and Jordan, protesters clashed with police, while peaceful demonstrations were held in Khartoum, Sudan, Russia, Mali, Senegal, and [[Mauritania]]. [[RT (TV network)|RT]] reported that a million people attended a demonstration in [[Grozny]], the [[capital city]] of the [[Chechnya|Chechen Republic]], protesting against the [[depictions of Muhammad]] in ''Charlie Hebdo'' and proclaiming that [[Islam]] is a religion of peace. One of the slogans was "Violence is not the method".{{cite web| title='Love to Prophet Mohammed': Crowds protest Charlie Hebdo cartoons in Chechnya| publisher=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]| date=19 January 2015| accessdate=19 January 2015| url=http://rt.com/news/224051-russia-chechen-rally-1mln/}} Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov declared a regional holiday and denounced "people without spiritual and moral values" in front of an audience estimated to range between 600,000 and a million people.{{Cite web|url = http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/188502/why-russia-is-no-place-to-be-charlie|title = Why Russia is No Place to Be Charlie|date = January 23, 2015|accessdate = January 4, 2016|website = Tablet|publisher = |last = Davidzon|first = Vladislav}} One week after the murders, [[Donald Trump]] mocked ''Charlie Hebdo'', saying the magazine reminded him of another "nasty and dishonest" satirical publication and that the magazine was on the verge of financial collapse.''The Independent'', [https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/donald-trump-charlie-hebdo-tweets-twitter-president-terrorism-coverage-islamic-state-a7569586.html Donald Trump's mocking tweets about Charlie Hebdo resurface after President criticises terrorism coverage], February 8, 2017 A British [[NGO]], the [[Islamic Human Rights Commission]], gave their 2015 international 'Islamophobe of the Year' award to ''Charlie Hebdo'',{{cite news|last1=Richards|first1=Victoria|title=Charlie Hebdo: Murdered staff given 'Islamophobe of the Year' award|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-murdered-staff-given-islamophobe-of-the-year-award-10100317.html|accessdate=11 March 2015|work=The Independent|date=11 March 2015}} whereas another British organisation, the [[National Secular Society]], awarded the ''Charlie Hebdo'' staff with [[Secularist of the Year]] 2015 "for their courageous response to the terror attack". The magazine said it would donate the associated £5,000 prize money to the fund that supports the families of the murdered cartoonists.{{cite news| title = Charlie Hebdo staff awarded Secularist of the Year prize for their response to Paris attacks| url = http://www.secularism.org.uk/news/2015/03/charlie-hebdo-staff-awarded-secularist-of-the-year-prize-for-their-response-to-paris-attacks| publisher = NSS| date = 28 March 2015| accessdate = 28 March 2015 }} == Post-attack == [[File:Global Debout - Place de la République, 2016.05.15 (4).jpg|thumb|upright|Place de la République, 2016.05.15]] Following some controversies over the paper's future following the 2015 attack,{{cite web|last1=Picquard|first1=Alexandre|title=" La vie à "Charlie" n’a jamais été un fleuve tranquille " |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/actualite-medias/article/2015/05/18/la-vie-a-charlie-n-a-jamais-ete-un-fleuve-tranquille_4634998_3236.html|website=Le Monde|accessdate=21 July 2015}} Charb's 40% stake in ''Charlie Hebdo'' was purchased from his parents by Riss and Eric Portheault, who were as of July 2015 sole shareholders in the paper. ''Charlie Hebdo'' switched to a new legal press publisher status which requires 70% of profits to be reinvested.{{cite web|title=" Charlie Hebdo " devient la première " entreprise solidaire de presse " |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/actualite-medias/article/2015/07/17/charlie-hebdo-devient-la-premiere-entreprise-solidaire-de-presse_4687647_3236.html|website=Le Monde|accessdate=21 July 2015}} === Other controversies === ''Charlie Hebdo'' was accused of attacking freedom of press when its lawyer Richard Malka tried to prevent the publication of the magazine ''Charpie Hebdo'', a pastiche of ''Charlie Hebdo''.[http://www.francetvinfo.fr/economie/medias/charlie-hebdo/quand-charlie-hebdo-veut-faire-interdire-charpie-hebdo_828099.html Quand "Charlie Hebdo" veut faire interdire "Charpie Hebdo"], ''Francetvinfo'', 18 February 2015. [[File:Charlie_Hebdo_September_14_cover.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Coco (cartoonist)|Coco]]'s artwork on the front cover of ''Charlie Hebdo'' on 14 September 2015 illustrates a parody of racist attitudes that proclaim that migrants are "welcome" but are treated as footstools. The speech balloon, "This [land] is your home", is a reference to a famous nationalist phrase, "This is our home".]] [[Daniel Schneidermann]] argues that the 2015 attack raised the profile of the paper internationally with non-Francophone audiences, meaning that only parts of the paper are selectively translated into English, making it easy to misrepresent the editorial stance of the publication and the purpose of provocative work.{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.fr/story/112747/charlie-hebdo-nouveau-victime-paradoxal-succes|title=Charlie Hebdo de nouveau victime de son paradoxal succès|work=Slate.fr|language=fr|date=14 Jan 2016}} [[Nadine Morano]] was offended at being drawn as a baby with Down syndrome after making remarks supporting the [[National Front (France)|National Front]].{{cite web|url=http://www.francetvinfo.fr/economie/medias/charlie-hebdo/charlie-hebdo-on-se-moque-de-nadine-morano-pas-des-handicapes-explique-la-dessinatrice-coco_1118621.html|title="Charlie Hebdo" : "On se moque de Nadine Morano, pas des handicapés", explique la dessinatrice Coco|author=Elise Lambert|work=francetv info}} One year after the attack, the weekly featured a caricature of [[Yahweh]] with a Kalashnikov rifle. The Vatican and Jewish groups said they were offended,{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/vatican-newspaper-denounces-woeful-charlie-hebdo-cover-102419477.html|title=Vatican newspaper denounces 'woeful' Charlie Hebdo cover|date=6 January 2016|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=26 March 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/152125/chief-rabbi-ephraim-mirvis-says-charlie-hebdo-god-cartoon-insulting-believers|title=Chief Rabbi Ephraim Mirvis says Charlie Hebdo 'God' cartoon is insulting to believers|date=|work=thejc.com|accessdate=26 March 2016}} and the [[Associated Press]] censored images of the cover.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2016/01/07/ap-removes-images-of-god-as-terrorist-charlie-hebdo-cover/|title=AP removes images of God-as-terrorist Charlie Hebdo cover|author=Erik Wemple|date=7 January 2016|work=Washington Post|accessdate=26 March 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/blog/2016/01/07/associated-press-self-censors-anniversar|title=Associated Press Self-Censors Anniversary Charlie Hebdo Cover|date=|work=Reason.com|accessdate=26 March 2016}} The 14 September 2015 edition's cover cartoon by [[Coco (cartoonist)|Coco]] depicted a migrant being maltreated by a man who proclaims "welcome to refugees" - in order to parody European claims about compassion.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/16/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-mocks-europes-response-to-migrant-crisis-with-cartoons-of-dead-syrian-boy.html?_r=0|title=Charlie Hebdo Mocks Europe’s Response to Migrant Crisis With Cartoons of Dead Syrian Boy|work=New York Times}} Riss wrote an editorial on the [[European migrant crisis]], arguing that it was hypocritical for Hungarian politicians to declare themselves compassionate because of their Christian beliefs, but at the same time reject migrants from Syria. Riss parodied anti-immigrant attitudes by featuring a cartoon with a caricature of Jesus walking on water next to a drowning Muslim boy, with the caption "this is how we know Europe is Christian". The cartoons were widely seen as [[gallows humour]] in France, but prompted another wave of controversy abroad.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.fr/2015/09/15/dessins-charlie-hebdo-migrants-aylan-internautes-scandalises_n_8137844.html|title=Les dessins de "Charlie Hebdo" sur la mort du petit Aylan scandalisent les internautes à l'étranger|date=15 September 2015|work=Le Huffington Post|language=fr}} That issue also included a caricature of the dead body of Syrian Kurdish refugee child [[Alan Kurdi]] next to a McDonald's sign with the caption, "So close to his goal."{{Cite web|title = Charlie Hebdo Cartoon Depicts Drowned Toddler Aylan Kurdi as Future Sexual Harasser|url = http://europe.newsweek.com/charlie-hebdo-aylan-kurdi-cologne-cartoon-415358?rm=eu|website = Newsweek|access-date = 2016-01-14}} In response to criticism, cartoonist [[Coco (cartoonist)|Corinne Rey]] said that she was criticising the consumerist society that was being sold to migrants like a dream.{{Cite news|title = Charlie Hebdo Mocks Europe’s Response to Migrant Crisis With Cartoons of Dead Syrian Boy|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/16/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-mocks-europes-response-to-migrant-crisis-with-cartoons-of-dead-syrian-boy.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-09-15|access-date = 2016-01-14|issn = 0362-4331|first = Robert|last = Mackey}} After the [[New Year's Eve sexual assaults in Germany]], a January 2016 edition included a cartoon by Riss about Kurdi, reflecting fickle sentiment towards refugees by including a caption questioning whether the boy would have grown up to be an "ass groper in Germany".{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/the-charlie-hebdo-cartoon-about-aylan-kurdi-and-sex-attackers-is-one-of-its-most-powerful-and-a6812346.html|title=The Charlie Hebdo cartoon about Aylan Kurdi and sex attackers is one of its most powerful|author=Jessica Brown|date=14 January 2016|work=The Independent}}{{Cite web|title = Charlie Hebdo cartoon depicts grown-up Aylan Kurdi as 'ass groper in Germany'|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-sparks-new-controversy-with-cartoon-depicting-aylan-kurdi-as-an-ass-groper-in-germany-a6810331.html|website = The Independent|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = en-GB}}{{Cite news|title = Charlie Hebdo cartoon depicting drowned child Alan Kurdi sparks racism debate|url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jan/14/charlie-hebdo-cartoon-depicting-drowned-child-alan-kurdi-sparks-racism-debate|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2016-01-14|access-date = 2016-01-14|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB}}{{Cite web|title = Charlie Hebdo backlash over 'racist' Alan Kurdi cartoon - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35306906|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = en-GB}} Following the crash of [[Metrojet Flight 9268]], which killed 224 civilians, mostly [[Russia]]n women and children,"[https://www.rt.com/news/320304-sinai-plane-crash-relatives/ ‘We are flying home’: Grief & disbelief in Russia over shocking Sinai air crash]". ''RT.'' 7 November 2015. and was seen as a probable [[List of terrorist incidents in October 2015|terrorist attack]], ''Charlie Hebdo'' published cartoons which were widely perceived as mocking the victims of the tragedy. One of the cartoons showed a victim's blue-eyed skull and a burned-out plane on the ground, with the caption: "The dangers of Russian low cost" flights. The other showed pieces of the plane falling on an [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] (ISIS) fighter with the caption: "Russia's air force intensifies its bombing." A spokesman for [[Vladimir Putin]] called the artwork "sacrilege", and members of the [[State Duma]] called for the magazine to be banned as extremist literature and demanded an apology from France.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34747432|title=Russia hits out at Charlie Hebdo over crash cartoon|work=BBC News}} On 2 September 2016, following the [[August 2016 Central Italy earthquake]], which caused 294 deaths, the French magazine published a cartoon in which the earthquake victims are depicted as pasta dishes, under the title "Séisme à l'italienne".{{cite web|title=Charlie Hebdo draws Italian anger with cartoon portraying earthquake victims as pasta|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/02/charlie-hebdo-draws-italian-anger-with-cartoon-portraying-earthq/|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=5 September 2016}} The reaction of Italians was unleashed on social networks so that, on the official Facebook page of the magazine, the cartoonist Coco pointed out with another cartoon: "Italians ... it's not Charlie Hebdo who builds your houses, it's the Mafia!"https://www.facebook.com/106626879360459/photos/a.106706332685847.10430.106626879360459/1236792179677251/?type=3&theater The French ambassador in Rome, in a statement, pointed out that the French Government's position on the Italian earthquake is not that expressed by ''Charlie Hebdo''.{{cite web|title=French embassy disowns Charlie Hebdo cartoons|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/2016/09/02/french-embassy-disowns-charlie-hebdo-cartoons_d716f1a1-075e-4212-b087-c14f61678b84.html|website=ANSA|accessdate=5 September 2016}} On 29 December 2016, Russia accused ''Charlie Hebdo'' of 'mocking' the [[2016 Russian Defence Ministry Tupolev Tu-154 crash|Black Sea plane crash]] after publishing 'inhuman' cartoons about the disaster. {{lead rewrite|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Bahá'í sidebar}} '''Covenant-breaker''' is a term used by [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'ís]] to refer to a person who has been [[Excommunication|excommunicated]] from the Bahá'í community for the act of '''covenant-breaking,''' roughly defined as active opposition to the Bahá'í Faith from a current member. According to [[Bahá'í laws|Bahá'í law,]] only the head of the religion, currently the [[Universal House of Justice]], has the authority to declare a person a covenant-breaker.
A person may be declared a covenant-breaker for actions which are seen as challenging the unity of the Bahá'í community, not for personal matters such as failure to obey Bahá'í law or conversion to another religion.
When a person is a declared a covenant-breaker all Bahá'ís are expected to avoid unnecessary association with that person.
==Definition== Covenant-breaking does not refer to attacks from non-Bahá'ís or former Baha'is. Rather, it is in reference to internal campaigns of opposition where the Covenant-breaker is seen as challenging the unity of the Bahá'í Faith, causing internal division, or by claiming or supporting an alternate succession of authority or administrative structure. The central purpose of the covenant is to prevent schism and dissension.<ref name="bahai-library1">[http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant Covenant, The, and Covenant-breaker<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In a letter to an individual dated 23 March 1975, the Universal House of Justice wrote: {{quote|When a person declares his acceptance of Bahá'u'lláh as a Manifestation of God he becomes a party to the Covenant and accepts the totality of His Revelation. If he then turns round and attacks Bahá'u'lláh or the Central Institution of the Faith he violates the Covenant. If this happens every effort is made to help that person to see the illogicality and error of his actions, but if he persists he must, in accordance with the instructions of Bahá'u'lláh Himself, be shunned as a Covenant-breaker.}}
The term 'Covenant-breaker' or, in Arabic 'naqid al-mithaq' [pl. Naqidu 'l-mithaq], was first used by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] to describe the partisans of his brother [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí]], who challenged his leadership. In `Abdu'l-Bahá's [[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá|Will and Testament]], He appointed [[Shoghi Effendi]] as the ''[[Guardian (Bahá'í Faith)|Guardian]]'' of the religion and called for the eventual election of the [[Universal House of Justice]], and defined in the same manner opposition to these two institutions as Covenant-Breaking. `Abdu'l-Bahá advised all Bahá'ís to shun anyone opposing the Covenant: "...one of the greatest and most fundamental principles of the Cause of God is to shun and avoid entirely the Covenant-breakers, for they will utterly destroy the Cause of God, exterminate His Law and render of no account all efforts exerted in the past."<ref>''The Will And Testament of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá'', [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/wt-2.html#gr10 p 20]</ref>
==Categorization==
=== Included categories of people === Most Covenant-breakers are involved in schismatic groups, but not always. For example, a Bahá'í who refuses to follow guidance on treatment of Covenant-breakers is at risk of being named one. One article<ref>[http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant The Covenant, and Covenant-breaker], by [[Moojan Momen]]</ref> originally written for the Bahá'í Encyclopedia, characterized Covenant-breakers that have emerged in the course of Bahá'í history as belonging to one of four categories:
#Leadership challenge: These are persons who dispute the authority and legitimacy of the head of the religion and advance claims either for themselves or for another. The main examples of these are [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí]] and [[Mason Remey|Charles Mason Remey]]. #Dissidence: Those who actively disagree with the policies and actions of the head of the faith without, however, advancing an alternative claim for leadership. This group consisted mostly of opponents of the Bahá'í administration such as [[Ruth White (Bahá'í author)|Ruth White]] and [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]]. #Disobedience: Those who disobey certain direct instructions from the head of the religion. Mostly the instruction in question is to cease to associate with a Covenant-breaker. Examples of this type include most of the descendants of `Abdu'l-Bahá during Shoghi Effendi's time. #Apostates who maliciously attack the Bahá'í Faith. Examples include [[Abd al-Hosayn Ayati|Ávárih]] and [[Níkú]].
=== Excluded categories of people === Shoghi Effendi wrote to the National Spiritual Assembly of Canada in 1957: {{quote|People who have withdrawn from the Cause because they no longer feel that they can support its Teachings and Institutions sincerely, are not Covenant-breakers -- they are non-Bahá'ís and should just be treated as such. Only those who ally themselves actively with known enemies of the Faith who are Covenant-breakers, and who attack the Faith in the same spirit as these people, can be considered, themselves, to be Covenant-breakers.<ref>Shoghi Effendi, Messages to Canada, p. 64</ref>}}
Beyond this, many other relationships to the Bahá'í Faith exist, both positive and negative. Covenant-breaking does not apply to most of them. The following is a partial list of those who could not rightly be termed Covenant-breakers:
* Members of other religions or no religion--with or without any particular relationship to the Bahá'í Faith. * Bahá'ís who simply leave the religion. (see above) * Bahá'ís who, in the estimation of the head of the religion have insufficiently understood the nature of the covenant from the start. These are sometimes "disenrolled" and are considered to have never actually been Bahá'ís, given their fundamental diversion from this core Bahá'í doctrine.
===Bábís=== [[Bábís]] are generally regarded as another religion altogether. Since Covenant-breaking presumes that one has submitted oneself to a covenant and then broken it, and Bábís never recognized or swore allegiance to Bahá'u'lláh, they are not Covenant-breakers.
Followers of [[Subh-i-Azal]], Bahá'u'lláh's half-brother who tried to poison him, engaged in active opposition to Bahá'ís, and Shoghi Effendi did inform Bahá'ís that they should avoid contact with his descendants, writing that "No intelligent and loyal Baha'i would associate with a descendant of Azal, if he traced the slightest breath of criticism of our Faith, in any aspect, from that person. In fact these people should be strenuously avoided as having an inherited spiritual disease -- the disease of Covenant-breaking!".<ref>Shoghi Effendi, From letter dated 9 December 1948 to an individual believer</ref>
==Covenant-breaking in Shoghi Effendi's immediate family== Through the influence of [[Bahá'u'lláh's family|Bahiyyih Khanum]], the eldest daughter of [[Bahá'u'lláh]], everyone in the household initially rallied around [[Shoghi Effendi]] after the death of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]]. For several years his brother Husayn and several cousins served him as secretaries. The only ones publicly opposing him were [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí]] and his followers, who were declared Covenant-breakers by `Abdu'l-Bahá. Contrary to `Abdu'l-Bahá's specific instruction, certain family members established illicit links with those whom `Abdu'l-Bahá had declared Covenant-breakers. After Bahiyyih Khanum died in 1932, Shoghi Effendi's eldest sister – Ruhangiz – married a son of [[Bahá'u'lláh's family|Siyyid Ali Afnan]]. Bahá'u'lláh's son-in-law was, thus, a long-standing enemy of `Abdu'l-Bahá (who had declared him a Covenant-breaker.) Through Ruhangiz's efforts, Shoghi Effendi's other sister and his cousin Thurayya also married sons of Siyyid Ali Afnan. Presumably being faced with a choice between shunning their disobedient family members and being themselves disobedient to `Abdu'l-Bahá and Shoghi Effendi, his cousins, aunts and uncles chose the latter.
===Ruhi Afnan=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Ruhi Afnan.jpeg|thumb|Shoghi Effendi (sitting) and Ruhi Afnan (standing)]] -->
After years of silence on these developments, cables sent by [[Shoghi Effendi]] on November 2, 1941 provide background to developments among family members. Ruhi Afnan, Shoghi Effendi's cousin through [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]]'s daughter Tuba:
* "Ruhi's sister married Covenant-breaker Faydi whose mother joined and supported arch-enemy Muhammad-`Ali and whose father `Abdu'l-Bahá denounced openly and repeatedly as His deadly enemy. Ruhi's family concurred. Inform all believers all manner communication excommunicated family forbidden."
Faydi was the son of [[Bahá'u'lláh's family#Furughiyyih|Furughiyyih Khanum]], a daughter of [[Bahá'u'lláh]] by his third wife [[Bahá'u'lláh's family#Gawhar|Gawhar]]. Furughiyyih and her children all supported [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí]]. Faydi had two elder brothers. Hussein Effendi Afnan was aide-de-camp to [[Faisal II of Iraq]] and Nayyer Effendi Afnan was Commissioner of Parks in Cairo, Egypt. The entire Bahá'í Family was stigmatized by Shoghi Effendi as Covenant-breakers as he was displeased with their marriages.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sohrab |first=Ahmad|authorlink=Ahmad Sohrab |title=Abdul Baha's Grandson Story of a Twentieth Century Excommunication |page = 166 |url=https://www.abebooks.com/Abdul-Bahas-Grandson-Story-Twentieth-Century/18337084751/bd |publisher= Universal Publishing Company, New York |date= 1943}}</ref>
Then in a 1950 cable:
* "Inform friends that Ruhi, his mother, with Ruha, his aunt, and their families, not content with years of disobedience and unworthy conduct, are now showing open defiance."<ref>{{cite book |last=Effendi |first=Shoghi |authorlink=Shoghi Effendi||date=February 22, 2015 |title=Citadel of Faith |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/CF/cf-6.html#pg87 |publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform |page=87 |isbn=978-1508530596}}</ref> (''Citadel of Faith'', p. 87)
And in 1953:
* "Treacherous Ruhi Afnan, not content with previous disobedience, correspondence with [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]], contact with old Covenant-breakers, sale, in conjunction with other members of family, of sacred property purchased by Founder of Faith, and allowing his sister to marry son of `Abdu'l-Bahá's enemy, is now openly lecturing on Bahá'í movement, claiming to be its exponent and is misrepresenting the teachings and deliberately causing confusion in minds of authorities and the local population. Inform National Assemblies." (''Messages to the Bahá'í World – 1950–1957'', p. 48)
Later, Ruhi was presented with a copy of Sohrab's book about his excommunication:
:"… under ordinary circumstances he would have been very much elated, and therefore thankful to see someone make such records of his services to the Cause, but that the references to the [[Guardian (Bahá'í Faith)|Guardian]] and the Administration changed his attitude completely. He did not wish to be defended; he felt that he must suffer in silence and be true to the Master’s last will and testament. Then Ruhi Effendi referred to Ahmad as being in the same plight as himself, but reacting differently. He thought this very regrettable." [p. 281]<ref>[http://www.h-net.msu.edu/~bahai/notes/vol2/newhist1.html From Gaslight to Dawn 10-19<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Munib Shahid=== Concerning [[Munib Shahid]], Shoghi Effendi's cousin through `Abdu'l-Bahá's daughter Ruha, Shoghi Effendi sent the following cable to the Bahá'í world in November 1944:
* "Monib Shahid, grandson of both `Abdu'l-Bahá and the [[Núrayn-i-Nayyirayn|King of Martyrs]], married according to the Moslem rites the daughter of a political exile who is [[Jamal al-Husayni|nephew]] of the [[Grand Mufti of Jerusalem]]. This treacherous act of alliance with enemies of the Faith merits condemnation of entire Bahá'í world."<ref>{{cite news | date=December 1944|title=Messages from the Guardian |url=https://bahai.works/Baha%27i_News/Issue_172 |newspaper=Bahá'í News|issue=172 |access-date=May 8, 2016 }}</ref> (''Bahá'í News'', No. 172)
===Husayn Ali===
Husayn Ali was Shoghi Effendi's brother. In April 1945, Shoghi Effendi sent the following cable to the Bahá'í world: "My faithless brother Husayn, after long period of dishonourable conduct, has abandoned the Master's home to consort with his sister and other Covenant-breakers"<ref>{{cite news | date=April 1945 |title=Messages from the Guardian |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File%3ABaha%27i_News_174.pdf&page=2|newspaper=Bahá'í News|issue=174 |access-date=May 8, 2016 }}</ref> (''Bahá'í News'', No. 174, p.2). In March 1950, Shoghi Effendi would send a further cable: "Faithless brother Hussein, already abased through dishonorable conduct over period (of) years followed by association with Covenant-breakers (in) Holy Land and efforts (to) undermine Guardian's position, recently further demeaned himself through marriage under obscure circumstances with lowborn Christian girl (in) Europe" <ref>{{cite news | date=March 1950 |title=Faithless Brother |url=https://bahai.works/Baha%27i_News/Issue_229|newspaper=Bahá'í News|issue=229 |access-date=May 8, 2016 }}</ref> (''Bahá'í News'', No. 229, p.1). Shoghi Effendi would later defend the use of the term "lowborn Christian girl" as follows: "Regarding his cable concerning Hussein: he has been very surprised to note that the terms 'low-born Christian girl ' and 'disgraceful alliance' should arouse any question; it seems to him that the friends should realize it is not befitting for the Guardian's own brother, the grandchild of the Master, an [[Afnán]] and [[Aghsán]] mentioned in the Will and Testament of the Master, and of whom so much was expected because of his relation to the family of the Prophet, to marry an unknown girl, according to goodness knows what rite, who is not a believer at all"<ref>{{cite news | date=October 1950|title=Hussein |url=https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File%3ABaha%27i_News_236.pdf&page=4 |newspaper=Bahá'í News|issue=236 |access-date=May 8, 2016 }}</ref> (''Bahá'í News'', No. 236, p.4).
===Riaz=== Concerning his own brother Riaz, the following cable was sent in December 1951:
* "With feeling profound concern, grief, indignation, am compelled disclose Bahá'í world recent developments Holy Land furnishing further incontestable proof relationship established old and new Covenant-breakers demonstrating increasing boldness, marked, tragic decline in character and spiritual condition grandchildren `Abdu'l-Bahá. Their shameful attitude and conduct receiving approbation their elders. Evidences multiplying attesting Ruhi's increasing rebelliousness, efforts exerted my eldest sister pave way fourth alliance members family Siyyid Ali involving marriage his granddaughter with Ruha's son and personal contact recently established my own treacherous, despicable brother Riaz with [[Mírzá Músá#Family|Majdi'd-Din]], redoubtable enemy Faith, former henchman Muhammad-'Ali, Archbreaker Bahá'u'lláh's Covenant. Convey information all National Assemblies."<ref>{{cite book |last=Effendi |first=Shoghi |date=1999 |title=Messages to the Bahá’í World: 1950–1957 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/mbw-13.html|publisher=Baha'i Publishing Trust|page=16 |isbn= 978-0877432500}}</ref> (''Messages to the Bahá'í World – 1950–1957'', p. 16)
===Mehrangiz=== He dispatched a cable concerning his younger sister in December 1941:
* "Sister Mehrangis [Mehrangiz] followed example Ruhi's [Ruhi] sister Justice demands announce believers her expulsion.".<ref>{{cite book |last=Effendi |first=Shoghi |title=The unfolding destiny of the British Baha'i community: Messages from the Guardian of the Baha'i Faith to the Baha'is of the British Isles |page = 149 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/UD/ud-158.html |publisher= UK Bahá’í Publishing Trust|date= December 1981 |isbn=978-0900125430}}</ref>(''Unfolding Destiny'', p. 149)
The reason for her being declared a Covenant-breaker was that she followed the example of Ruhi's sister by marrying to one of his cousins without the Guardian's consent. Mehrangiz married to Hassan Afnan, the son of [[Bahá'u'lláh's family#Furughiyyih|Furughiyyih Khanum]], a daughter of Bahá'u'lláh by his third wife [[Bahá'u'lláh's family#Gawhar|Gawhar]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Sohrab |first=Ahmad|authorlink=Ahmad Sohrab |title=Abdul Baha's Grandson Story of a Twentieth Century Excommunication |page = 22 |url=https://www.abebooks.com/Abdul-Bahas-Grandson-Story-Twentieth-Century/18337084751/bd |publisher= Universal Publishing Company, New York |date= 1943}}</ref>
==Resultant groups== {{main|Bahá'í divisions}} {{unsourced section|date=February 2017}} Most of the groups regarded by the larger group of Bahá'ís as Covenant-breakers originated in the claims of Charles Mason Remey to the [[Guardian (Bahá'í Faith)|Guardianship]] in 1960. The [[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá]] states that Guardians should be [[lineal primogeniture|lineal descendant]]s of [[Bahá'u'lláh]], that each Guardian must select his successor during his lifetime, and that the nine [[Hands of the Cause of God]] permanently stationed in the [[holy land]] must approve the appointment by majority vote. Bahá'ís interpret lineal descendency to mean physical familial relation to Bahá'u'lláh, of which Mason Remey was not.
Almost all of Bahá'ís accepted the determination of the [[Hands of the Cause]] that upon the death of Shoghi Effendi, he died "without having appointed his successor". There was an absence of a valid descendant of Bahá'u'lláh who could qualify under the terms of `Abdu'l-Bahá's will. Later the [[Universal House of Justice]], initially elected in 1963, made a ruling on the subject that it was not possible for another Guardian to be appointed.
In 1960 Remey, a Hand of the Cause himself, retracted his earlier position, and claimed to have been coerced. He claimed to be the successor to Shoghi Effendi. He and the small number of people who followed him were expelled from the Faith by the Hands of the Cause. Those close to Remey claimed that he went senile in old age, and by the time of his death he was largely abandoned, with his most prominent followers fighting amongst themselves for leadership.
The largest group of the remaining followers of Remey, members of the so called "[[Orthodox Bahá'í Faith]]", believe that legitimate authority passed from Shoghi Effendi to Mason Remey to Joel Marangella. They, therefore, regard the Universal House of Justice in Haifa, Israel to be illegitimate, and its members and followers to be Covenant-breakers.
The present descendants of expelled members of Bahá'u'lláh's family have not specifically been declared Covenant-breakers, though they mostly do not associate themselves with the Bahá'í religion.
A small group of Bahá'ís in Northern New Mexico believe that these descendants are eligible for appointment to the Guardianship and are waiting for such a direct descendant of Bahá'u'lláh to arise as the rightful Guardian.
There is also a small group in Montana, originally inspired by Leland Jensen, who claimed a status higher than that of the Guardian. His failed apocalyptic predictions and unsuccessful efforts to reestablish the Guardianship and the administration were apparent by his death in 1996. A dispute among Jensen's followers over the identity of the Guardian resulted in another division in 2001.
